thread.title: Amercian eels kept off endangered species list
thread.title_full: Amercian eels kept off endangered species list

author: app.com
title: Amercian eels kept off endangered species list
text:
MORE The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced on Wednesday that the American eel is stable and does not need protection under the Endangered Species Act (ESA).
The decision, also known as a 12-month finding, follows an in-depth status review on a 2010 petition to list the eel as threatened under the ESA.
The review was largely based on a biological species report peer-reviewed by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration-Fisheries, U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Forest Service, the Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission’s Eel Technical Committee and academia.
Eels have been under fishing and environmental pressure on a number of fronts. The demand for eels in Asian markets had led to heavy fishing for glass eels, eels which are still in the larval stage, which are shipped overseas alive to mature.
Hundreds of millions of American eel larvae return from the sea to freshwater, estuarine and marine waters every year. American eels have been harvested for thousands of years by Native American cultures, and were an important part of the diet of early colonial settlers.
After examining the best scientific and commercial information available regarding past, present and future stressors facing the species, the Service determined the eel’s single population is overall stable and not in danger of extinction or likely to become endangered within the foreseeable future.
Nonetheless, for the species’ long-term stability, the agency recommends continuing efforts to maintain healthy habitats, monitor harvest levels, and improve river passage for migrating eels.
The life of the American eel begins and ends in the Sargasso Sea in the North Atlantic Ocean. Millions of adult American eels leave waters from as far north as Greenland and south to Venezuela to reproduce in the Sargasso Sea.
